TopicTitle: [1.12.x] Cryogenic Engines: Liquid Hydrogen and Methane Rockets! (Jan 22, 2022)

Articles.Content: Yes, the difference is that you need to use ModuleManager to target the correct BOILOFFCONFIG block inside ModuleCryoTank to add that OUTPUT\_RESOURCE block.

This is a great mod that adds a lot of diversity when designing rocket stages. Building a rocket that takes advantage of cryogenic fuel is a challenge.

If anyone's wondering what this mod changes when building rockets with LH2 engines, well, it depends. **Cryogenic Engines can make your rocket more expensive or less expensive**, **but they *will* surely make it taller.**

Smaller rockets will always be more expensive and 50% to 100% taller, but big rockets might be either more, or less less expensive (but still taller). It depends on the engines used, so it's worth experimenting.

Examples:

Spoiler

**1.** Comparing the deltaV with the same weights (but who cares about the weight?)

Using a Mk1-25 command pod and a Jumbo tank for reference, I took 2 smaller tanks for <abbr title="Liquid Fuel">LF</abbr>/Ox that weighed exactly as much as the bigger hydrolox one. The engines used in the comparison were the top-of-the-line vacuum 'Terrier' (345s <abbr title="Specific Impulse (rocketry) or Internet Service Provider">ISP</abbr>) and the hydrolox equivalent, also top-of-the-line vacuum 'Hecate' (465s <abbr title="Specific Impulse (rocketry) or Internet Service Provider">ISP</abbr>). They weigh practically the same and have practically the same thrust.

Using the cryogenic fuel in the rocket and a tank that weighed exactly as much as the stock one, the deltaV increased by 20% for the same weight, the size of the cryogenic tank was just a bit over 2 times larger, and the cost of the cryo tank+fuel+engine was about 4 times more expensive than the stock cost.

**2.** Keeping the same deltaV and the same <abbr title="Thrust-to-weight ratio">TWR</abbr> with a 1.25 Mun rocket: stock PT Series Munsplorer with 3.5 <abbr title="Liquid Fuel">LF</abbr>/O stages versus a modified PT Series Munsplorer with 1 <abbr title="Liquid Fuel">LF</abbr>/O + 2.5 LH2/O stages (the lander had to use <abbr title="Liquid Fuel">LF</abbr>/O for size purposes):

The almost-cryogenic 1.25 Mun rocket became about 50% taller, 15% more expensive and 35% lighter. Still not worth it to use cryogenic engines (unless you want to shave off some weight... but why?)

**3.** A massive 5 meter-wide **335t** 7000dV lifter for a 11.5 payload (and a 0.8t fairing) with also a <abbr title="Liquid Fuel">LF</abbr>/O lander:

The cryogenic version was **12% LESS expensive** (yay!) 45% lighter and only 1/3rd taller, surprisingly.

When it comes to the individual stages:

Cryo, top to bottom: 16k credits, 36,6k credits and 43,2k credits.

Kerbolox, top to bottom: 16.1k credits, 30.2k credits and 68,7k credits.

As you see, LH2 first stages have the most potential to decrease the costs.

Same question here.

I searched all configs, also those in my <abbr title="Realism Overhaul (mod)">RO</abbr> backups, and did not find anything helpful.

Edit:

Perhaps it's necessary to patch away the boiloffconfig block and then patch a weird ResourceConverter into the tank, that converts LqdHydrogen to Hydrogen when no EC/s is used, and does NOT convert LqdHydrogen to Hydrogen when EC/s is used.

So a "negative" power consuming resource converter that needs electric power to NOT convert.

**Edited <time datetime="2020-09-23T12:01:05Z" title="09/23/2020 12:01  PM" data-short="3 yr">September 23, 2020</time> by Gordon Dry**

> 
> 
> On 9/23/2020 at 6:58 AM, Krzeszny said:
> 
> 
> Nice mod.
> 
> 
> 
> 
> If anyone's wondering what this mod changes when building rockets, I've done a super simple comparison. In short, the mod adds a very expensive way (I'm talking up to 5 times) to increase the deltaV by something around 20% while making the rocket 2 times bigger. For fans of huge rockets that can afford to build them.
> 
> 
> 
> 
> Using a Mk1-25 command pod and a Jumbo-sized LH2/Ox tank for reference, I also took 2 smaller tanks for <abbr title="Liquid Fuel">LF</abbr>/Ox that weighed exactly as much as the bigger hydrolox one. The engines used in the comparison were the top-of-the-line vacuum 'Terrier' (345s <abbr title="Specific Impulse (rocketry) or Internet Service Provider">ISP</abbr>) and the hydrolox equivalent, also top-of-the-line vacuum 'Hecate' (465s <abbr title="Specific Impulse (rocketry) or Internet Service Provider">ISP</abbr>). They weigh practically the same and have practically the same thrust.
> 
> 
> 
> 
> Using the cryogenic fuel in the rocket and a tank that weighed exactly as much as the stock one, the deltaV increased by 20% for the same weight, the size of the cryogenic tank was just a bit over 2 times larger, and the cost of the cryo tank+fuel+engine was about 4 times more expensive than the stock cost.
> 

Which, if you assume that each <abbr title="Liquid Fuel and Oxidizer">LFO</abbr> stage is normally 2.5x the mass of it's payload (3.5x including it's payload), and you have a 10ton final payload on a 3-stage rocket, means that a <abbr title="Liquid Fuel">LF</abbr>/O rocket might be: 10\*3.5^3 = 428.75t [1]. If you make all 3 stages cryo, your stage ratio is (2.5\*.8)+1 = 3, so 10\*3^3 = 270t. 63% the mass. The rocket equation adds up! (In practice you might increase <abbr title="Delta-V">Dv</abbr> instead and go to a 2.5 stage design, but that's more complicated)  

EDIT: You can compute any hybrid, assuming there is no <abbr title="Liquid Fuel and Oxidizer">LFO</abbr> stage above a cryo stage, as: (P\*3^C)\*3.5^L, where P is payload mass, C is the number of cryo stages on top, and L is the number of <abbr title="Liquid Fuel and Oxidizer">LFO</abbr> stages below.

> 

I didn't know about that rocket equation. Nice to know. About that mass ratio constant, how can you be sure that 2.5x applies to all rockets and not just LFOx-powered ones (let's call them *kerbolox*)?

Also, the <abbr title="Specific Impulse (rocketry) or Internet Service Provider">ISP</abbr> I used was the vacuum <abbr title="Specific Impulse (rocketry) or Internet Service Provider">ISP</abbr>, so I imagine the deltaV would be much different and also incomparable during launches, as hydrolox and kerbolox rocket engines have different start and end points when it comes to their <abbr title="Specific Impulse (rocketry) or Internet Service Provider">ISP</abbr>'s.

> 
> 
> 2 minutes ago, Krzeszny said:
> 
> 
> I didn't know about that rocket equation. Nice to know. About that mass ratio constant, how can you be sure that 2.5x applies to all rockets and not just LFOx-powered ones (let's call them *kerbolox*)?
> 
> 
> 
> 
> Also, the <abbr title="Specific Impulse (rocketry) or Internet Service Provider">ISP</abbr> I used was the vacuum <abbr title="Specific Impulse (rocketry) or Internet Service Provider">ISP</abbr>, so I imagine the deltaV would be much different and also incomparable during launches, as hydrolox and kerbolox rocket engines have different start and end points when it comes to their <abbr title="Specific Impulse (rocketry) or Internet Service Provider">ISP</abbr>'s.
> 

In reality, you would probably keep the mass ratio the same, and increase delta-v, then remove a stage if possible. But that's too complex and specific for this rough estimate. It was intended more as a demonstration of how these efficiency gains grow exponentially.

Tharsis's extended model has an error caused by the animation ![nCDFOlf.png](https://i.imgur.com/nCDFOlf.png)

Speaking of extending nozzles, would it be possible to have different Isp with the nozzle extended and retracted? Maybe it's a good idea for a future update.

The [CryoEnginesRestock](https://github.com/ChrisAdderley/CryoEngines/tree/master/Extras/CryoEnginesRestock "CryoEnginesRestock")  patch makes the  LH2 Rhino   completely <abbr title="1. Original Post(er). The first post in a thread, or the person who posted it. 2. Overpowered. A part or mechanic that upsets game balance by being too powerful."><abbr title="1. Original Post(er). The first post in a thread, or the person who posted it. 2. Overpowered. A part or mechanic that upsets game balance by being too powerful.">OP</abbr></abbr> if Etna is the baseline. Patched LH2 Rhino compared to Etna has higher <abbr title="Thrust-to-weight ratio"><abbr title="Thrust-to-weight ratio">TWR</abbr></abbr> , 1.5x higher thrust, half the cost, higher Isp (and a smaller size if I recall?)

Had a weird issue with Cryo Tanks where selecting a foil tank would cause FPS to drop below 1, and the tanks had both foil and polyhedral textures. I reverted to 1.5.3 and the performance was fixed, but not the textures. (Reverting Core also didn't seem to make a difference)

**CryoEngines 1.2.0**

- Marked for KSP 1.11.x
- Updated DynamicBatteryStorage to 2.2.1
- Updated B9PartSwitch to 2.17.0
- Updated CryoTanks to 1.5.5
- Updated DeployableEngines to 1.2.3
- Updated ModuleManager to 4.1.4
- Waterfall configuration for all engines
- Stromboli can be stored in inventories
